Attention Mercer County Residents:

Strong broadband internet access is key in educating our children. Unfortunately, not everyone has access to this resource. Mercer County Better Together (MCBT) is a local non-profit organization that is building a plan to expand broadband internet in Mercer County. This project is led by a local team designed to best represent Mercer County - if you do not have reliable internet service right now, MCBT would love to hear from you! Your perspective will help MCBT build a plan that best serves our children, our families, our businesses and our communities. To learn more or to share your experiences, contact MCBT Executive Director Kyle McEwen via email at kyle@mcbettertogether.org or by phone at (309) 574-3123.

Apollo Elementary School, Mercer County School District #404
August 19 at 1:53 PM ·

Wednesday Morning Update:

All the students are in their classrooms for the third day. Each morning has been smoother than the last. Your children are adapting to our new circumstances and tolerating the masks and social distancing well. Our plan is not perfect but I believe it is working as well as we could have hoped. I would like to take this opportunity to publicly thank all the teachers and staff at Apollo for all their hard work in preparing for this week and their ability to make lemonade out of lemons. I witnessed a lot of learning going on yesterday and it was happening in the classrooms, and in the woods and under the shade trees. Our staff has really risen to the occasion.

I would also like to thank all the parents for the patience, understanding, and grace they have shown us as we get this year under way.

It has been a whole community effort.

Bill Fleuette, Principal

Prom update. Now that we have hit phase 4 and have guidance from the state, we had to make the hard decision to officially cancel our 2020 Prom. Quad City Arts' HS Art Invitational Online Gallery

Each spring, Quad City Arts shows works from top Quad City high school visual artists and their art teachers. The exhibit fills the walls of Quad City Arts’ downtown Rock Island gallery, the opening ceremony is attended by hundreds of Quad Citians supporting young artistic talent, and students receive thousands of dollars in awards from exhibition sponsors. The 43rd Annual High School Art Invitational is getting an unexpected update to the traditional gallery exhibit, because of COVID-19 precautions and Illinois’ stay-at-home order.

Even though the gallery is currently closed, Quad City Arts is committed to making this show happen, so the artwork will be available for public viewing through an online gallery, allowing students to show their artwork in a formal gallery setting and to compete for over $5,000 in scholarships and prizes.

This mandatory closure takes effect Tuesday, March 17. Currently, we anticipate the closure to last through March 30.

Mercer County Schools will continue to provide continuous learning opportunities in any way that we are able through our recently developed e-learning plan. In addition we will make every effort to provide meals for all children who need them. Many questions are yet to be answered, and we will do our best under these extraordinary circumstances. More updates will be forthcoming.
